X.T: Send Gitlab CI Reports & Artifacts by E-mail with MailGun
X.ST: Most users migrating from Jenkins to GitLab CI are looking for a way to send emails with the reports when a test fails. While Gitlab CI can notify you that a job has failed (or was successful) it will not attach any files or reports to that email.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Mailgun to send emails from a GitLab pipeline.

X.T: Automating with GitLab Duo, Part 1: Generating tests

ARTICLE.COMMENT: There is almost no information in this article, and the choice to indicate in the file name that the tests are generated by GitLab Duo is nonsensical. We do not care if an LLM helped write the tests; a human developer is responsible for checking and modifying them before committing them to the codebase.

X.T: Automating with GitLab Duo, Part 2: Complex testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Once again, I find strange that the author writes that GitLab Duo is a kind of tests. LLMs are a tool to help write code which can be production code or test code for any kind of test.

X.T: Automating with GitLab Duo, Part 3: Validating testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This short article compares tests written manually and with GitLab Duo, but it only considers code coverage, the fact that tests have a real functionnal meaning seems to not be taken into account. By the way, we now understand why they suffixed the filenames by duo.py.

X.T: GitLab Duo with Amazon Q: DevSecOps meets agentic AI

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab Duo integrates Amazon Q to generate an MR from an issue, to upgrade the code, to perform code reviews, and to generate unit tests.

X.T: GitLab names Bill Staples as new CEO

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A classic message when a company gets a new CEO.

X.T: Transform code quality and compliance with automated processes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some marketing propaganda, there is no real information here.

X.T: Introducing GitLab Advanced Vulnerability Tracking

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article just says that you can do better than using only the file path and the line number in order to track moving code (e.g. to not report once again some violations already reported as false positives). This is obvious! It is a pity that JulianThome does not explain a little how they implemented a better solution.

X.T: Improve AI security in GitLab with composite identities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab introduces composite identities so that an AI agent can access data or perform an action only if both the agent and the human who launched it have the authorisation to do it.

X.T: How GitLab uses prompt guardrails to help protect customers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some marketing message for reassuring managers on the security of AI. But there are no details and they are too much positive, ignoring that jailbreaking is still a common thing.

X.T: The Co-Create Program: How customers are collaborating to build GitLab

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the Co-Create Program, and the examples of Thal√®s, Scania, and Kitware.

X.T: How to scan a full commit history to detect sensitive secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors describe historic scans and highlight the different secret detections available in GitLab.

X.T: GitLab Duo Workflow: Enterprise visibility and control for agentic AI

ARTICLE.COMMENT: 100% bullshit targetting managers.

X.T: GitLab Duo Self-Hosted: Enterprise AI built for data privacy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab supports some models deployed locally or in a private cloud.

X.T: Prepare now: Docker Hub rate limits will impact GitLab CI/CD

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is now possible to log in and to sign commits using a YubiKey.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab and HackerOne are now integrated.

X.T: Unlocking AI for every GitLab Premium and Ultimate customer

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Code Suggestions and Chat, both in IDE, are now available for Premium and Ultimate users.

X.T: 4 ways to accelerate embedded development with GitLab

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab explains that the development best practices can be applied, more or less, to embedded software, so it would be a good idea to use GitLab for this one.

X.T: How we decreased GitLab repo backup times from 48 hours to 41 minutes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A fix of a Git bottleneck resulted into a huge speedup of the backups.

X.T: Vibe coding with GitLab Duo Agent Platform: 'Issue to MR' Flow

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab is also doing semantic diffusion: this is not vibe coding, but having a coding agent generate a MR draft from an issue.

X.T: Supercharge your Git workflows

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Git Much Faster, a script performing a highly optimised Git clone, but you need to understand its limitations.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation on using GitLab Duo for MR review. But this demo is pitiful: the review found places where the code doesn‚Äôt even compile. Who would submit such an MR?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Atlassian ending Data Center as GitLab maintains deployment choice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab tries to convince the clients of Atlassian‚Äôs Data Center products to migrate to GiLab.

X.T: GitLab engineer: How I improved my onboarding experience with AI

ARTICLE.COMMENT: KonstantinGreif describes how GitLab Duo helped him onboard in GitLab, but this smells mostly like marketing bullshit.

X.T: Building trust in agentic tools: What we learned from our users

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors explain that users get confidence in agents slowly, use after use. This is partially true. For example, GitLab has to prove that their AI tools are more or less at the same level than all the other tools: if you try twice to do something that you know Claude can handle and GitLab fails, you just give up experimenting with it.

X.T: Strengthening GitLab.com security: Mandatory MFA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitLab will enforce the use of MFA.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the preconfigured agents, the custom ones (which seem to simply be system prompts‚Ä¶), and the external agetns (currently, only Claude and Codex are supported).
